     387             :   // function.
     388             :

     401             :   // method after it.
     402             : 
     403             :   // Use the effective user ID to determine the user name.

     852             : ACE_INLINE int
     853             : ACE_OS::rename (const char *old_name,
     854             :                 const char *new_name,
     855             :                 int flags)
     856             : {
     857             : # if defined (ACE_LACKS_RENAME)
     858             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (old_name);
     859             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (new_name);
     860             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     861             :   ACE_NOTSUP_RETURN (-1);
     862             : # elif defined (ACE_HAS_WINCE)
     863             :   // Win CE is always wide-char.
     864             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     865             :   if (0 == ::MoveFile (ACE_TEXT_CHAR_TO_TCHAR (old_name),
     866             :                        ACE_TEXT_CHAR_TO_TCHAR (new_name)))
     867             :     ACE_FAIL_RETURN (-1);
     868             :   return 0;
     869             : # elif defined (ACE_WIN32) && !defined (ACE_LACKS_WIN32_MOVEFILEEX)
     870             :   // NT4 (and up) provides a way to rename/move a file with similar semantics
     871             :   // to what's usually done on UNIX - if there's an existing file with
     872             :   // <new_name> it is removed before the file is renamed/moved. The
     873             :   // MOVEFILE_COPY_ALLOWED is specified to allow such a rename across drives.
     874             :   if (flags == -1)
     875             :     flags = MOVEFILE_COPY_ALLOWED | MOVEFILE_REPLACE_EXISTING;
     876             :   if (::MoveFileExA (old_name, new_name, flags) == 0)
     877             :     ACE_FAIL_RETURN (-1);
     878             :   return 0;
     879             : #elif defined (ACE_RENAME_EQUIVALENT)
     880             :   return ACE_RENAME_EQUIVALENT (old_name, new_name);
     881             : # else
     882             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     883             :   return ::rename (old_name, new_name);
     884             : # endif /* ACE_HAS_WINCE */
     885             : }
     886             : 
     887             : #if defined (ACE_HAS_WCHAR)
     888             : ACE_INLINE int
     889             : ACE_OS::rename (const wchar_t *old_name,
     890             :                 const wchar_t *new_name,
     891             :                 int flags)
     892             : {
     893             : # if defined (ACE_LACKS_RENAME)
     894             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (old_name);
     895             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (new_name);
     896             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     897             :   ACE_NOTSUP_RETURN (-1);
     898             : # elif defined (ACE_HAS_WINCE)
     899             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     900             :   if (::MoveFileW (old_name, new_name) == 0)
     901             :     ACE_FAIL_RETURN (-1);
     902             :   return 0;
     903             : # elif defined (ACE_WIN32) && !defined (ACE_LACKS_WIN32_MOVEFILEEX)
     904             :   // NT4 (and up) provides a way to rename/move a file with similar semantics
     905             :   // to what's usually done on UNIX - if there's an existing file with
     906             :   // <new_name> it is removed before the file is renamed/moved. The
     907             :   // MOVEFILE_COPY_ALLOWED is specified to allow such a rename across drives.
     908             :   if (flags == -1)
     909             :     flags = MOVEFILE_COPY_ALLOWED | MOVEFILE_REPLACE_EXISTING;
     910             :   if (::MoveFileExW (old_name, new_name, flags) == 0)
     911             :     ACE_FAIL_RETURN (-1);
     912             :   return 0;
     913             : # elif defined (ACE_WIN32)
     914             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (flags);
     915             :   return ::_wrename (old_name, new_name);
     916             : # else
     917             :   ACE_Wide_To_Ascii nold_name (old_name);
     918             :   ACE_Wide_To_Ascii nnew_name (new_name);

     920             : # endif /* ACE_HAS_WINCE */
     921             : }
     922             : #endif /* ACE_HAS_WCHAR */

     992             : #endif /* ACE_LACKS_TEMPNAM */

    1088             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (format);

    1097             : ACE_INLINE int
    1098             : ACE_OS::vsprintf (wchar_t *buffer, const wchar_t *format, va_list argptr)
    1099             : {
    1100             : # if (defined _XOPEN_SOURCE && (_XOPEN_SOURCE - 0) >= 500) || \
    1101             :      (defined (sun) && !(defined(_XOPEN_SOURCE) && (_XOPEN_VERSION-0==4))) || \
    1102             :       defined (ACE_HAS_VSWPRINTF) || \
    1103             :       (defined (_MSC_VER) && !defined (ACE_HAS_WINCE))
    1104             : 
    1105             :   // The XPG4/UNIX98/C99 signature of the wide-char sprintf has a
    1106             :   // maxlen argument. Since this method doesn't supply one, pass in
    1107             :   // a length that works (ULONG_MAX doesn't on all platform since some check
    1108             :   // to see if the operation will remain in bounds). If this isn't ok, use
    1109             :   // ACE_OS::snprintf().
    1110             :   return vswprintf (buffer, 4096, format, argptr);
    1111             : 
    1112             : # elif defined (__MINGW64_VERSION_MAJOR) && !defined (WIN64)
    1113             :   // the MingW64 32bit version causes link errors when using the
    1114             :   // 'standard' vswprint(). Luckily they have a mingw special.
    1115             : 
    1116             :   return __mingw_vswprintf (buffer, format, argptr);
    1117             : 
    1118             : # elif defined (ACE_WIN32)
    1119             :   // Windows has vswprintf, but the pre-VC8 signature is from the older
    1120             :   // ISO C standard. Also see ACE_OS::snprintf() for more info on this.
    1121             : 
    1122             :   return vswprintf (buffer, format, argptr);
    1123             : 
    1124             : # else
    1125             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (buffer);
    1126             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (format);
    1127             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (argptr);
    1128             :   ACE_NOTSUP_RETURN (-1);
    1129             : 
    1130             : # endif /* XPG5 */
    1131             : }
    1132             : #endif /* ACE_HAS_WCHAR */
    1133             : 
    1134             : ACE_INLINE int
    1135             : ACE_OS::vsnprintf (char *buffer, size_t maxlen, const char *format, va_list ap)
    1136             : {
    1137             : #if !defined (ACE_LACKS_VSNPRINTF)
    1138             :   int result;
    1139             : # if defined (ACE_WIN32) && !defined (ACE_HAS_C99_VSNPRINTF)
    1140             :   result = ::_vsnprintf (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1141             : 
    1142             :   // Win32 doesn't regard a full buffer with no 0-terminate as an overrun.
    1143             :   if (result == static_cast<int> (maxlen) && maxlen > 0)
    1144             :     buffer[maxlen-1] = '\0';
    1145             : 
    1146             :   // Win32 doesn't 0-terminate the string if it overruns maxlen.
    1147             :   if (result == -1 && maxlen > 0)
    1148             :     buffer[maxlen-1] = '\0';
    1149             : # else
    1150             :   result = ::vsnprintf (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1151             : # endif
    1152             :   // In out-of-range conditions, C99 defines vsnprintf() to return the number
    1153             :   // of characters that would have been written if enough space was available.
    1154             :   // Earlier variants of the vsnprintf() (e.g. UNIX98) defined it to return
    1155             :   // -1. This method follows the C99 standard, but needs to guess at the
    1156             :   // value; uses maxlen + 1.
    1157             :   if (result == -1)
    1158             :     {
    1159             :       result = static_cast <int> (maxlen + 1);
    1160             :     }
    1161             : 
    1162             :   return result;
    1163             : #elif defined (ACE_HAS_TRIO)
    1164             :   return trio_vsnprintf (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1165             : #elif defined (ACE_HAS_VSNPRINTF_EMULATION)
    1166             :   return vsnprintf_emulation (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1167             : #else
    1168             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (buffer);
    1169             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (maxlen);
    1170             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (format);
    1171             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (ap);
    1172             :   ACE_NOTSUP_RETURN (-1);
    1173             : #endif /* ACE_LACKS_VSNPRINTF */
    1174             : }
    1175             : 
    1176             : #if defined (ACE_HAS_WCHAR)
    1177             : ACE_INLINE int
    1178             : ACE_OS::vsnprintf (wchar_t *buffer, size_t maxlen, const wchar_t *format, va_list ap)
    1179             : {
    1180             : # if (defined _XOPEN_SOURCE && (_XOPEN_SOURCE - 0) >= 500) || \
    1181             :      (defined (sun) && !(defined(_XOPEN_SOURCE) && (_XOPEN_VERSION-0==4))) || \
    1182             :       defined (ACE_HAS_VSWPRINTF) || \
    1183             :       defined (ACE_WIN32)
    1184             : 
    1185             :   int result;
    1186             : 
    1187             : # if defined (ACE_WIN32) && !defined (ACE_HAS_C99_VSNWPRINTF)
    1188             :   // Microsoft's vswprintf() doesn't have the maxlen argument that
    1189             :   // XPG4/UNIX98 define. They do, however, recommend use of _vsnwprintf()
    1190             :   // as a substitute, which does have the same signature as the UNIX98 one.
    1191             :   result = ::_vsnwprintf (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1192             : 
    1193             :   // Win32 doesn't regard a full buffer with no 0-terminate as an overrun.
    1194             :   if (result == static_cast<int> (maxlen) && maxlen > 0)
    1195             :     buffer[maxlen-1] = '\0';
    1196             : 
    1197             :   // Win32 doesn't 0-terminate the string if it overruns maxlen.
    1198             :   if (result == -1 && maxlen > 0)
    1199             :     buffer[maxlen-1] = '\0';
    1200             : # else
    1201             :   result = vswprintf (buffer, maxlen, format, ap);
    1202             : #endif
    1203             : 
    1204             :   // In out-of-range conditions, C99 defines vsnprintf() to return the
    1205             :   // number of characters that would have been written if enough space
    1206             :   // was available.  Earlier variants of the vsnprintf() (e.g. UNIX98)
    1207             :   // defined it to return -1. This method follows the C99 standard,
    1208             :   // but needs to guess at the value; uses maxlen + 1.
    1209             :   // Note that a formatting failure also returns -1. On RHEL this is
    1210             :   // errno EINVAL. Don't indicate a simple memory shortage for that.
    1211             :   if (result == -1 && errno != EINVAL)
    1212             :     result = static_cast <int> (maxlen + 1);
    1213             : 
    1214             :   return result;
    1215             : # else
    1216             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (buffer);
    1217             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (maxlen);
    1218             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (format);
    1219             :   ACE_UNUSED_ARG (ap);
    1220             :   ACE_NOTSUP_RETURN (-1);
    1221             : # endif /* platforms with a variant of vswprintf */
    1222             : }
    1223             : #endif /* ACE_HAS_WCHAR */
